title: Have Brighton left themselves short of a striker after selling Joao Pedro?
description: Hurzeler says teens Tzimas and Kostoulas aren't Premier League-ready, leaving only Rutter and Welbeck as senior options. Are they enough?
content:
Midway through the second half of Brighton & Hove Albion’s 2-0 away defeat against Everton, a double substitution by Fabian Hurzeler raised an uncomfortable question: have they left themselves short up front after selling Joao Pedro to Chelsea earlier this summer?

Head coach Hurzeler’s side were two goals down on Sunday afternoon when he made straight swaps at left-back and in midfield, introducing Ferdi Kadioglu for Maxim De Cuyper and Diego Gomez for Yasin Ayari.

There was no out-and-out striker named on the bench — Brajan Gruda, who is a No 10 or right-winger, came on in the closing minutes — as an injury that ruled out Georginio Rutter left Hurzeler depending on Danny Welbeck. The 34-year-old former England international looked rusty in what was his first start of the season; Rutter had led the attack, with Welbeck a substitute, in the opening game — a 1-1 home draw against Fulham last Saturday.

Ex-Manchester United and Arsenal front man Welbeck missed a good chance to put Brighton ahead and silence the home support during the first half of Everton’s first-ever league game at Hill Dickinson Stadium. He could not sort his feet out and his effort went over the crossbar although, in fairness, the cross from Yankuba Minteh was a little behind him when a yard in front would have made the opportunity far simpler.

Welbeck, now Brighton’s first-choice taker after Joao Pedro’s £50million-plus move to Chelsea in July, also had a poorly struck 74th-minute penalty saved by Jordan Pickford after Matt O’Riley had converted from the spot to open the scoring against Fulham. Of far more concern than who should be on penalties — this was Welbeck’s second failure in six career attempts — is the need to keep him and Rutter fit.

And for U.S. readers

A total of £50million has been spent this year on Greek teenagers Stefanos Tzimas and Charalampos Kostoulas (£20m on Kostoulas from Nurnberg in a winter-window deal that sent him back to the German side for the rest of last season, £30m on Kostoulas from Olympiacos in June). But neither is deemed by Hurzeler to be ready for the Premier League yet.

Hurzeler spoke at his pre-match media session on Thursday about the importance of the youngsters getting “their bodies adapted to the intensity of the Premier League” after run-outs for Brighton’s under-21 side. He is treading carefully in particular with Tzimas, who has suffered a leg muscle injury in the same area “twice or three times in a row”, which the German said “creates doubts in a player”.

As much as this approach makes sense, it places too much of a burden on Rutter and Welbeck being available. Hurzeler’s team could be playing catch-up in the Premier League by the time Tzimas and Kostoulas are ready to increase the competition at the top end of the pitch, with Evan Ferguson having been loaned to Italy’s Roma for the season and Julio Enciso in the process of signing for the BlueCo group that owns Chelsea and French top-flight side Strasbourg.

Brighton should have at least four points, arguably six, after these first two games, not one. Having conceded a 96th-minute equaliser against Fulham, they were better than Everton yesterday and created the clearer chances — Kaoru Mitoma and Jan Paul van Hecke hit the woodwork in the first half, and O’Riley should have scored when he latched onto a James Tarkowski backpass but was not decisive enough to beat Pickford.

Instead, one point from the first two matches is Brighton’s worst Premier League start since their 2017-18 debut season, when that first point came in the third game. With Manchester City up next at the Amex Stadium on Sunday, it is a tough environment for gaining momentum when the points tally is out of sync with performances.

If he’d been fit, Rutter would have started again on Merseyside. “Yesterday, he had a small issue in training and, unfortunately, then we had to make the decision,” Hurzeler told The Athletic during his press conference after the game. “It’s only a small issue. I am sure that he will be back soon.”

Rutter didn’t play again last season after an ankle injury sustained in the FA Cup quarter-final defeat to Nottingham Forest near the end of March, and the absence of the imposing Frenchman arguably cost Hurzeler’s side a place in Europe: they took only one point from the first four league games he missed on the run-in and finished eighth, four points behind Forest.

While he can play as the No 9, Rutter is more of a handful as a marauding No 10 — he earned that penalty against Fulham with a powerful run from a relatively deep position.

Hurzeler told reporters in the run-up to the Everton match that his £40million record signing from Leeds United last summer is a “great connector” who “gives energy to everyone” with his positive, always smiling persona.

Welbeck can be relied upon when he is fully up to speed. But having been affected by injuries throughout his career, he played a limited part in the latter stages of Brighton’s pre-season programme.

Hurzeler, asked whether he felt short of attacking options to get back into Sunday’s game, where the visitors trailed 2-0 early in the second half after Iliman Ndiaye and James Garner found the net for Everton, told reporters: “If we scored the goals, we won’t have this discussion. We created so many chances. Not only chances — big, big chances.

“I wouldn’t say it, because it would only be an excuse if I said we missed a striker or did not have enough offensive opportunities to change (things). Overall, we created enough to win this game. We had enough chances to score. That’s the main thing to take away, no matter how many options we had.”

Further additions were not being ruled out before the Everton defeat. There will be no transfer-market panic from owner-chairman Tony Bloom before the summer window shuts a week today, but the issue of replacing Joao Pedro’s 30 goals in 70 appearances, including 15 penalties, lingers.
summary: Brighton & Hove Albion's 2-0 away defeat against Everton has raised concerns about their lack of a striker after selling Joao Pedro to Chelsea. Head coach Fabian Hurzeler made a double substitution during the second half of the match, introducing Ferdi Kadioglu for Maxim De Cuyper and Diego Gomez for Yasin Ayari, while no out-and-out striker was named on the bench. This decision left Brighton's first-choice striker, Danny Welbeck, unable to replace him due to an injury that left Georginio Rutter. The team's overall performance has been criticised, with one point from two matches, marking their worst Premier League start since 181818. The need to keep Welbeck and Rutter fit is also a concern, particularly as this approach puts too much of a burden on them.
shortSummary: Brighton's coach Fabian Hurzeler's double substitution during a 2-0 defeat to Everton raises concerns about shortfalls after selling Joao Pedro to Chelsea, relying on Danny Welbeck for goals.

argos_summary: Brighton & Hove Albion lost 2-0 to Everton, raising questions about their attacking depth after selling Joao Pedro to Chelsea. Head coach Fabian Hurzeler struggled with limited options, as injuries to Georginio Rutter and Danny Welbeck left the team short of a traditional striker, and he relied on midfielders and a late substitute to fill the gap. Hurzeler defended his tactics, citing the need to develop young talents like Stefanos Tzimas and Charalampos Kostoulas while maintaining a focus on fitness and squad depth. The defeat left Brighton with only one point from two games, their lowest start since their debut season, and highlighted the urgency of strengthening the front line before the next fixtures.
